The Parliament met at 9.30 a.m., MR. SPEAKER [THE HON. (DR.) JAGATH
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES OFFICIAL REPORT THE DEMOCRATIC SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF SRI LANKA

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) I wish to announce to Parliament that I have received the Determinations of the Supreme Court in respect of the Bill titled Presidents Entitlements (Repeal), which was challenged in the Supreme Court under Article 121(1) of the Constitution.
The Supreme Court has determined that no provision of the Bill is inconsistent with any provision of the Constitution and can be enacted by Parliament with a simple majority.

Further, the Supreme Court has rejected Petition No. SC/SD/29/2025 filed in this regard on the ground that the Petitioner had failed to comply with the mandatory provisions in Article 121(1) of the Constitution in invoking the jurisdiction of the Court.
I order that the Determinations of the Supreme Court be printed in the Official Report of todays Proceedings.

Hon. (Dr.) Harini Amarasuriya; I am very much thankful for your Answer. There are more than 3,000 students studying in this university. () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harini Amarasuriya) Hon. Speaker, there are several degree programmes being carried out by this university. So, each degree programme has to be assessed separately. We are doing our very best to make sure that the first batch of students graduate with adequate qualifications and a recognized degree. Some of the degree programmes are less complicated than the others, for which we are very confident we could give the students a solution fairly fast. But, some of the other degree programmes need to be assessed much more rigorously. So, we are appointing subject experts to advise us on how exactly we could make sure that these students graduate with a degree that is acceptable and that is of a quality standard recognized by the university system and other stakeholders as well. However, we do not intend to let any student graduate without that guarantee. That is what we are working towards.

() ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harsha de Silva) Hon. Presiding Member, we support the Resolution relating to the Agreement between the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates on the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments. This is the 29th such agreement we have entered into. We had signed 28 before. We hope that this would help improve investments by the United Arab Emirates in Sri Lanka.

But, Sir, there is a much more urgent matter brewing in the Middle East and even the United Arab Emirates has already pointed out that if Israel continues to go ahead with their plan to occupy the land of the Palestinians, they would cross the red-line and would damage the spirit of the Abraham Accords, which normalized the relationship between the two countries.

Sir, the world watches in horror as a humanitarian catastrophe of unprecedented scale unfolds in the Gaza Strip. It is a profound human tragedy that tests the moral fibre of every nation and demands that Sri Lanka not only affirm its principles, but also act upon them. Our nation has a proud history of solidarity with the Palestinian cause, a relationship rooted in our non-aligned Foreign Policy and shared experiences. The current Governments cautious posture represents a retreat from that principled legacy and our task is to urge them to return to decisive action.

Sir, the demographics of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem, the three key Occupied Territories that were on the Middle East map before 07th October, 2023, have fast been altered for nearly two years to date. It is brutally evident that new facts are being created on the ground through a deadly combination of political, military, ideology-based strategies which have snuffed out the innocent lives of more than 60,000 people and displaced over 2 million people, half of them children. The aggressors have now begun to target Palestinian people in the other areas of the Occupied Territory as well. No decent, democratic, conscientious nation or people could be reticent or worse, collusive over these violent catastrophes, which the world witnesses with shattered hearts day in and day out.

The fundamental premise that should have ideally underpinned a reasonably negotiated political settlement to the Palestinian question since 1948, the Nakba, which means forced displacement and dispossession of the Palestinians, have now been turned on their head. The right of the refugees of the Nakba era and their descendants to return to Palestine has effectively been throttled. Under international law, it is a right that should be fostered and facilitated. Rather, the reality today is far more ominous with more and more Palestinians risk expulsion or evacuation from their territories.

Contrary to the principles of the international humanitarian law, food, medicines and other essentials meant for a hungry, desperate and often-bleeding population are not just being denied, but are actively being blocked. We are now witnessing the expeditious undoing of all the principles and norms, which would have made the long-yearned-for two-State solution an ultimate reality. Historical revisionism continues to persist so defiantly in its political, military and socio-economic aspects, aided by active political and economic support, encouragement and even military assistance from a handful of powerful nations.
Sri Lanka recognized the State of Palestine as far back as 1989. Consequently, the Palestinian diplomatic representation in Colombo had been recognized as the

Embassy of the State of Palestine in terms of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations. It is our national responsibility to assert that recognition on every platform, regional and international as well as bilateral and multilateral. Not doing it as assiduously as such State recognition entails or behaving in a manner that chips away at the core of that recognition means that the Government does not care whether that State so recognized exists or goes off the face of the earth.

It is not just a treachery committed against the Palestinian people, but also an imprimatur of approval for the ongoing anti-Palestine abolitionist project, which, if successful, would undoubtedly have wider ramifications on regional security and stability, including on Sri Lanka. We, as Representatives of people, should ensure that the Palestinian people are not denied their due place and all attempts to reduce them to subhumans are frustrated.

Sir, the United Nations is marking its 80th Anniversary this year. The General Assembly, which begins its 80th Session today, would be a platform for countries to celebrate the legacy of the UN and to lament its manifold limitations as well. Sir, nothing in recent times has exposed the depths of the UN Security Councils inefficacy and unresponsiveness as much as the Gaza situation has done. It is important that the special gathering of world leaders should reaffirm the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination, which means more than mere expression of a two-State solution, but also the actual realization of a State for Palestinians in peaceful co-existence with its neighbours.

Sir, it is high time that the Government of Sri Lanka call a spade a spade and directly and unequivocally call for the end of occupation and the catastrophic military onslaughts and illegal settlement activities in Palestine. However, at no point can the terrorist actions of the Hamas be condoned. They must not be allowed to use the innocent people of Gaza to achieve their own objectives. As we all know, it is the killing of some 1,200 Israelis and the taking of another 250 hostage on 07th October, 2023 by the Hamas which set off this massive Israeli offensive. The sad truth is that it is the innocent on both sides who have paid and are paying with their lives for terrorism on both sides.
Therefore, Sir, it is a moment for Sri Lanka to rise to our moral responsibility, to honour our legacy and to join the growing chorus of nations which choose justice over expediency.
Thank you very much. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) . . .

( ) (The Hon. Rajeevan Jeyachandramoorthy) Hon. Presiding Member, I rise today to speak on the Agreement between the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates on the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments, which is before this House. This Agreement is of profound significance. It is not merely a legal framework, but also a renewed vision for Sri Lankas economic future built upon stability, partnership and shared prosperity.

Sir, at the time we gained Independence in 1948, Sri Lanka was regarded as the third richest country in Asia, only being behind Japan and Malaysia. With fertile lands, a highly literate population and being a strategic location in the Indian Ocean, the world expected Sri Lanka to become a model of growth and development. For decades, the ethnic conflict and social instability consumed our nation. While countries such as Malaysia, Singapore, and the United Arab Emirates opened their doors for foreign direct investment, Sri Lanka was struggling to ensure peace and unity at home.

Sir, let me recall one striking example. The global technology giant Motorola once considered Sri Lanka as a potential destination for its operations. But, due to instability and policy uncertainty, they chose Malaysia instead. That single investment became a spark for Malaysias transformation into a technology and manufacturing hub. Not only Motorola, but many other international companies bypassed Sri Lanka and invested in the UAE, Singapore and Malaysia, nations which had political stability, clear policy frameworks and investor confidence. That was a painful but important lesson for us. Opportunities lost cannot always be regained, but they can remind us never to repeat the same mistakes.

Sir, if there is a modern story of transformation, it is surely that of the United Arab Emirates. In less than five decades, the UAE evolved from a desert economy dependent on oil into a global hub for trade, finance, technology and tourism. Today, its cities, Dubai and Abu Dhabi, symbolize vision, planning and execution. Now, the UAE is a leader in artificial intelligence, renewable energy, fintech, logistics and modern infrastructure. It has shown the world that with foresight, innovation and determination, even a small nation with limited natural resources could achieve extraordinary success.

Sir, Sri Lanka and the UAE established diplomatic relations in 1979. Since then, our bilateral partnership has grown steadily in trade, investment and people-to-people ties. The UAE is home to nearly 300,000 Sri Lankan expatriates. They contribute significantly to the UAEs economy while also sending their valuable remittances home. These men and women are our unofficial ambassadors, strengthening the bonds of trust and friendship between our two countries. Trade between our nations is equally vital. The UAE is Sri Lankas seventh largest export market and the third largest source of import.
And also, this is not only about money, but about knowledge sharing, technology transferring and positioning Sri Lanka firmly on the global investment map.
( ) (The Hon. Rajeevan Jeyachandramoorthy) Sir, give me a minute.

I, therefore, urge this House to support and approve the Agreement between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates on Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of Investments. By doing so, we are not merely protecting investments, but also building a bridge of shared prosperity, ensuring that Sri Lanka never again misses opportunities in future as we once did in the past.

( ) (The Hon. Shanakiyan Rajaputhiran Rasamanickam) Hon. Presiding Member, participating in this Debate on the Resolution with regard to the Agreement between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates, I would like to urge the Government that before passing Resolutions on Agreements between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates or with other foreign countries, they must first focus on reaching an agreement with its own citizens, the fellow citizens of this country. Even though it has been a year since the Government came into power, it has failed to reach an agreement with the Tamil-speaking citizens of this country.

Sir, I would like to say a few words on this Resolution that is being debated today. But, before that, on behalf of our party, the Ilankai Tamil Arasu Kadchi, I would like to read out our response to the Statement made by the Hon. Minister of Foreign Affairs at the 60th Session of the UNHRC. I quote:
We refer to the statement made by Hon. Vijitha Herath at the 60th session of the UN Human Rights Council.

At the outset, we must record our deep disappointment on the governments response to several pressing issues of accountability and reconciliation that are still outstanding. This government came into office holding out several promises. However, one full year after the President was elected, we are yet to see even the beginnings of those promises being fulfilled.

Although the Minister states that strengthening national unity and reconciliation is integral to the development of the country, not even the low-hanging fruits have been harvested. Despite several assurances, the Prevention of Terrorism Act - PTA - is yet to be repealed. It is a matter of regret that having taken a firm position not to enact any new law to replace the PTA, the Minister now says that a new counter terrorism legislation would be introduced. PTA is continued to be used despite calls and assurances for a moratorium on its use until its repeal. Similarly, no steps have been taken to repeal the Online Safety Act.

The Ministers statement that external action will serve to create divisions and jeopardize national processes is hugely problematic, so is his opposition to the Si Lanka Accountability Project. A decade and a half after the conclusion of the armed conflict, there has been no internal mechanism for accountability whatsoever.

It is in this background; it is only natural for the victims to look for international involvement. The Minister makes no reference to the uncovering of clear evidence of genocidal intent at Chemmani, Jaffna where 240 skeletal remains have been found, most probably as a result of extra-judicial killing. It is a known fact that no local expertise is available for the identification of these victims. Even so, the government has not called for international assistance in this regard or in respect of many other cases of mass graves and enforced disappearances.

We note and thank the government of India for reiterating the call for meaningful devolution and their support to the aspiration of the Tamil community for equality, justice, dignity and peace. India has also called for the early conduct of Provincial Council elections and meaningful devolution of powers.

The Government of Sri Lanka on the other hand in their written response, has taken the position that the Provincial Council elections will be held after the delimitation process is over. This is a recipe to delay the Provincial Council election by at least several years. The Government is breaching its promise to the Tamil speaking people of the North and East by unduly denying their franchise. The Government must immediately give its assent to the Private Members' Bill moved by our Member of Parliament, Hon. Shanakiyan Rasamanickam and facilitate the holding of Provincial Council elections immediately."
This letter has been signed by our Partys Leader and the Secretary-General and I am also tabling* this letter on behalf of the Ilankai Tamil Arasu Kadchi.

() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Prof.) Ruwan Ranasinghe - Deputy Minister of Tourism) Hon. Speaker, today's Debate is on the Agreement between Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates on the Promotion and Reciprocal Protection of the Investments. This Agreement is expected to encourage UAE investors to explore Sri Lankas strategic positioning along the trade route in the Indian Ocean, making it an attractive destination for investment. It also establishes a secure legal framework to expand investment opportunities in global markets while ensuring the protection of foreign investments. The Agreement also facilitates and strengthens foreign investments between the two nations by ensuring investor protection, promoting economic cooperation and establishing comprehensive investment protection mechanisms, dispute resolution frameworks and policy structures. Sir, I took those objectives of the Agreement from its Keynote to stress the significance or importance of this particular Agreement and this Debate.

Sir, I was thinking whether I have been participating in a wrong debate or have been at a wrong place while listening to most of the speeches of the Members of the Opposition. As I mentioned, this is an important Agreement that we need to debate on. While debating, we need to make this a platform to add improvements to the Agreement because it is going to act as a foundation for rebuilding the economy, which had been bankrupted during the decades of rule by most of the Members who are sitting in front of us in the Opposition. It is shameful to see that some of the Members are still trying - a few made their points just a little while ago - to stimulate racist politics, using different languages, and I need to remind such Members to go and review the results of the last General Election. A large majority of those minorities, different nations, had clearly voted for this Government, categorically rejecting the racist political efforts of those politicians.
